The potential role of finger length ratios in the development of schizophrenia is that the 2d : 4d ratio may be an effective predictor of schizophrenia, with significant differences between schizophrenia and control groups concerning the ratio of the lengths of the second digit to the fourth digit, as well as its asymmetry, in both hands.

The study compared the finger length ratios of 103 male patients diagnosed with schizophrenia to 100 healthy male individuals and found significant differences in the 2D:4D ratio and its asymmetry between the two groups.

The 2d:4d asymmetry index was significantly lower in the patient group than the healthy control comparison group, and there were significant differences between the schizophrenia and control groups in respect of left 2d:4d and right 2d:4d.
The 2D:4D asymmetry index was found to be statistically significant in the study regarding finger length ratios and schizophrenia in males.
